hypotheses.source_question: How do age-associated changes in long-range chromatin contacts causally drive global chromatin architecture deterioration, and can targeted restoration of specific long-range interactions reverse aging phenotypes in mammalian cells?
hypotheses.statement: We hypothesize that age-associated loss of CTCF-anchored long-range chromatin contacts causally precedes and drives TAD boundary erosion, such that the temporal decay rate of specific inter-TAD contacts predicts subsequent local chromatin decompaction with a lead time of at least one cell passage.
hypotheses.mechanism: CTCF-cohesin complexes maintain long-range contacts that mechanically constrain chromatin into TADs. During aging, oxidative damage to CTCF binding sites and reduced cohesin loading cause specific long-range contacts to weaken first, removing the structural 'tethers' that maintain TAD boundaries. This untethering permits chromatin decompaction and heterochromatin spreading across former boundaries, constituting a causal chain from contact loss → boundary erosion → architectural collapse. The direction is contacts → architecture, not the reverse.
hypotheses.prediction: In longitudinal Hi-C data from replicatively aging cells, the decay rate of CTCF-anchored inter-TAD contacts at passage N will correlate with TAD boundary insulation score loss at passage N+1 with Pearson r > 0.5, and this correlation will be significantly stronger than the reverse temporal order (architecture at N predicting contacts at N+1), with a difference in correlation coefficients Δr > 0.15.
hypotheses.falsification_criteria: If TAD boundary erosion temporally precedes or occurs simultaneously with long-range contact loss (i.e., architecture-to-contact correlation at lag -1 is equal to or stronger than contact-to-architecture correlation at lag +1, Δr ≤ 0), this would refute the hypothesis that contact loss causally drives architectural deterioration and instead suggest contacts are downstream consequences or co-occurring phenomena.
hypotheses.minimum_effect_size: Pearson r > 0.5 for contact decay predicting boundary erosion; Δr > 0.15 difference between forward vs. reverse temporal correlation; explained variance > 25% for the predictive model.

experiment.approach: Perform temporal cross-correlation analysis on publicly available longitudinal Hi-C datasets from aging cells to test whether contact decay precedes boundary erosion, establishing causal ordering through Granger-style temporal precedence.
steps: Download longitudinal Hi-C datasets from replicatively aging IMR90 fibroblasts (4D Nucleome, GEO:GSE130275) spanning early to late passages (P10, P20, P30, senescent)
Process raw Hi-C reads with HiC-Pro and normalize with ICE; generate contact matrices at 25kb and 100kb resolution
Call TAD boundaries using insulation score method (cooltools) and quantify boundary strength at each passage
Identify CTCF-anchored long-range contacts (>500kb) by intersecting significant contacts (FitHiC2, q<0.01) with CTCF ChIP-seq peaks from matched or comparable cell types
For each CTCF-anchored contact, compute decay trajectory across passages; for each TAD boundary, compute insulation score trajectory
Perform cross-correlation analysis with temporal lag: correlate contact strength at passage N with boundary insulation at passage N+1, and vice versa
Apply Granger causality test to determine whether contact decay 'Granger-causes' boundary erosion
Validate findings in independent dataset (Senescence Cell Atlas Hi-C or BJ fibroblast aging data if available)
Control for global chromatin accessibility changes using matched ATAC-seq data to rule out confounding by general chromatin decondensation
experiment.estimated_effort: 3-4 weeks compute time including data download, processing, and statistical analysis
experiment.data_requirements: Longitudinal Hi-C data from aging human fibroblasts with ≥3 time points (available from 4D Nucleome and GEO); matched or comparable CTCF ChIP-seq; optional matched ATAC-seq for accessibility control
experiment.expected_positive: Contact decay at passage N correlates with boundary erosion at passage N+1 with r > 0.5; this forward correlation exceeds reverse correlation by Δr > 0.15; Granger causality test rejects null (p < 0.05) for contacts → boundaries but not boundaries → contacts
experiment.expected_negative: Forward and reverse temporal correlations are statistically indistinguishable (Δr ≤ 0.15) or boundary erosion precedes contact loss, indicating contacts are not causally upstream of architecture changes
experiment.null_hypothesis: H₀: The temporal decay of CTCF-anchored long-range contacts does not predict subsequent TAD boundary erosion better than the reverse temporal order; Δr ≤ 0 between forward and reverse lagged correlations.
experiment.statistical_test: Pearson correlation with Fisher z-transformation for comparing correlation coefficients; Granger causality test (F-test) with alpha=0.05; bootstrap confidence intervals (n=1000) for Δr; Bonferroni correction for multiple boundary comparisons
limitations: Longitudinal Hi-C datasets with sufficient temporal resolution are rare; may need to use cross-sectional data as proxy with reduced causal inference power
Replicative aging in culture may not fully recapitulate in vivo aging mechanisms
CTCF binding sites may shift with age, complicating contact identity tracking across passages
Granger causality establishes predictive precedence, not definitive causation—confounders affecting both contacts and boundaries could produce spurious temporal ordering
experiment.requires_followup: Wet-lab validation using dCas9-based loop engineering (CLOuD9 system) to artificially restore specific age-depleted CTCF contacts in senescent cells and measure whether this rescues local TAD boundary insulation scores, heterochromatin marks (H3K9me3), and SASP gene silencing

hypotheses.source_question: How does age-dependent dysregulation of histone-modifying enzyme relocation kinetics causally alter the epigenetic landscape and contribute to cellular senescence and organismal aging?
hypotheses.statement: We hypothesize that age-dependent slowing of histone-modifying enzyme relocation kinetics causally precedes and drives epigenetic entropy accumulation, such that computational modeling of enzyme trafficking delays will predict locus-specific histone modification variance observed in aged single-cell datasets.
hypotheses.mechanism: With age, nuclear transport machinery (importins/exportins) and chromatin accessibility at target loci degrade, causing histone-modifying enzymes like SIRT1 and EZH2 to relocate more slowly to DNA damage sites and regulatory regions. This kinetic delay creates temporal windows where competing enzymes deposit aberrant marks, and where stochastic mark turnover increases heterogeneity. The causal direction is: trafficking dysfunction → delayed enzyme arrival → increased stochastic modification → epigenetic entropy (not the reverse: entropy does not cause trafficking delays).
hypotheses.prediction: A computational model incorporating measured age-dependent nuclear transport rates and chromatin accessibility changes will explain >25% of the variance in locus-specific histone modification heterogeneity (H3K9ac, H3K27me3) observed between young and old single-cell epigenomic datasets, outperforming a null model using only steady-state enzyme abundance by >15 percentage points in explained variance.
hypotheses.falsification_criteria: If the kinetic relocation model explains ≤10% of the variance in age-dependent histone modification heterogeneity, OR if a steady-state enzyme abundance model explains equal or greater variance (within 5 percentage points), the causal primacy of relocation kinetics would be refuted. Additionally, if loci with predicted high relocation delays show LOWER modification variance than loci with predicted normal kinetics, the mechanism is falsified.
hypotheses.minimum_effect_size: Kinetic model R² > 0.25 for predicting locus-specific modification variance; improvement over abundance-only model ΔR² > 0.15; correlation between predicted relocation delay and observed modification entropy r > 0.4

experiment.approach: Build a stochastic kinetic model of histone-modifying enzyme relocation incorporating age-dependent nuclear transport rates and chromatin accessibility, then validate predictions against existing single-cell ATAC-seq and histone modification datasets from young versus aged samples.
steps: Step 1: Curate published nuclear transport kinetic parameters (importin-β, RanGTP gradients) from young versus aged cells from proteomics and imaging studies (e.g., Rempel et al. 2019, D'Angelo et al. 2009)
Step 2: Extract locus-specific chromatin accessibility from public single-cell ATAC-seq aging datasets (Tabula Muris Senis, human PBMC aging cohorts) to parameterize local enzyme arrival rates

Step 3: Build a stochastic differential equation model where enzyme arrival rate at each locus = f(nuclear transport rate × local accessibility × enzyme abundance), with modification state evolving via Gillespie algorithm
Step 4: Simulate histone modification dynamics (H3K9ac, H3K27me3) at 10,000+ loci under 'young' versus 'aged' kinetic parameters over 1000 cell divisions
Step 5: Calculate predicted modification entropy (Shannon entropy of mark states) per locus under each condition
Step 6: Download and process matched single-cell histone modification data (scCUT&Tag from Bartosovic et al., or imputed from scATAC via published models) for young/old mouse tissues
Step 7: Compute observed locus-specific modification variance across single cells in young versus aged samples
Step 8: Perform regression analysis: predicted kinetic-model entropy vs observed modification variance, compared to null model using only bulk enzyme ChIP-seq abundance
Step 9: Identify top 500 loci where model predicts largest age-dependent kinetic delays; test whether these show significantly higher modification variance than control loci
Step 10: Sensitivity analysis varying transport rate and accessibility parameters to identify which kinetic components most strongly drive entropy predictions
tools: Python/Julia for stochastic modeling (Gillespie algorithm implementation)
scCUT&Tag datasets (Bartosovic et al. 2021, mouse brain aging)
Published nuclear transport proteomics (D'Angelo lab datasets)
Gene Ontology enrichment for pathway validation
experiment.data_requirements: Public single-cell ATAC-seq from aged tissues (Tabula Muris Senis), scCUT&Tag histone data, published nuclear transport kinetic measurements, bulk ChIP-seq for enzyme occupancy baselines
experiment.expected_positive: Kinetic relocation model achieves R² > 0.25 for predicting locus-specific modification variance; outperforms abundance-only model by ΔR² > 0.15; loci with predicted high delays show significantly elevated modification entropy (Mann-Whitney p < 0.001)
experiment.expected_negative: Kinetic model R² ≤ 0.10, or abundance-only model performs equivalently (ΔR² < 0.05), or loci with high predicted delays show equal/lower variance than controls
experiment.null_hypothesis: H₀: Age-dependent changes in histone modification heterogeneity are fully explained by changes in steady-state enzyme abundance and do not require modeling of relocation kinetics; kinetic parameters add no predictive power beyond abundance measurements.
experiment.statistical_test: Nested model comparison using likelihood ratio test (α = 0.01) for kinetic vs abundance-only models; Pearson correlation with bootstrapped 95% CI for delay-entropy relationship; Mann-Whitney U test (α = 0.001, Bonferroni-corrected) for high-delay vs control loci variance comparison
limitations: Reliance on imputed histone marks from accessibility data introduces inference error
Nuclear transport parameters derived from different cell types/conditions than single-cell epigenomic data
Model assumes enzyme relocation is rate-limiting, but mark removal kinetics may also vary with age
Cannot distinguish cell-intrinsic aging from microenvironment effects in tissue-derived single-cell data
Correlation between model predictions and observations cannot definitively prove causation
experiment.requires_followup: Wet-lab validation using CRISPR-tagged SIRT1/EZH2 with live-cell imaging to directly measure relocation kinetics in young vs replicatively senescent human fibroblasts, followed by locus-specific CUT&RUN to confirm predicted modification variance at high-delay loci identified computationally

hypotheses.source_question: Does the progressive decline in chromatin buffering capacity with age causally precede and accelerate epigenetic erosion, or does accumulated epigenetic erosion functionally compromise buffering mechanisms?
hypotheses.statement: We hypothesize that the decline in chromatin buffering capacity causally precedes and accelerates epigenetic erosion during aging, mediated by reduced ATP-dependent chromatin remodeler activity that permits stochastic accumulation of aberrant histone modifications.
hypotheses.mechanism: ATP-dependent chromatin remodelers (particularly SWI/SNF family members like SMARCA4) maintain chromatin homeostasis by actively correcting spontaneous nucleosome mis-positioning and aberrant histone modifications. With age, declining NAD+/ATP ratios and reduced remodeler expression diminish this 'error-correction' capacity, causing a phase transition from buffered to unbuffered chromatin dynamics. Once buffering drops below a critical threshold, epigenetic errors accumulate autocatalytically because the machinery that would normally reverse them is compromised. Causal direction: buffering loss → erosion acceleration (not vice versa).
hypotheses.prediction: In longitudinal single-cell chromatin accessibility data, the rate of chromatin accessibility variance increase (erosion proxy) will show a sharp inflection point that occurs 2-4 cell divisions AFTER buffering capacity (measured as stress-response recovery half-time) drops below 70% of young-cell baseline, with Granger causality F-statistic > 4.0 for buffering→erosion but not erosion→buffering.
hypotheses.falsification_criteria: If epigenetic erosion metrics (accessibility variance, histone mark entropy) increase significantly BEFORE buffering capacity decline is detectable, OR if Granger causality analysis shows erosion→buffering with F > 4.0 while buffering→erosion shows F < 2.0, the hypothesis is refuted. Additionally, if partial epigenetic reprogramming restores erosion metrics without restoring buffering dynamics, this would indicate erosion is upstream.
hypotheses.minimum_effect_size: Granger causality F-statistic > 4.0 (p < 0.01) for buffering→erosion direction; temporal lag of buffering decline preceding erosion acceleration by ≥2 population doublings; explained variance of erosion rate by prior buffering state > 15%.

experiment.approach: Re-analyze published longitudinal single-cell ATAC-seq and CUT&Tag datasets from aging studies to extract both buffering dynamics (stress-response trajectories) and erosion metrics (accessibility variance), then apply causal inference methods to determine temporal ordering.
steps: Curate public single-cell chromatin datasets: prioritize Tabula Muris Senis ATAC-seq, Aging Cell Atlas, and any longitudinal reprogramming datasets (e.g., Sarkar et al. 2020 OSK studies) that include multiple timepoints

Define operational metrics: (a) Buffering capacity = coefficient of variation in accessibility at stress-responsive loci normalized to baseline, or recovery half-time after perturbation if time-series available; (b) Erosion = Shannon entropy of accessibility across regulatory elements + cell-to-cell variance at clock CpG-adjacent regions
For each cell type with sufficient temporal sampling (≥4 timepoints across lifespan), compute both metrics at each age and fit smoothing splines to extract rate-of-change
Apply Granger causality tests: regress erosion_rate(t) on buffering(t-1) + erosion(t-1) vs. buffering_rate(t) on erosion(t-1) + buffering(t-1); compute F-statistics for each direction
Implement convergent cross-mapping (CCM) as a nonlinear alternative to Granger for robustness check

Build a minimal ODE model: dB/dt = -k1*B - k2*E*B (buffering decay + erosion feedback); dE/dt = k3*(1-B/B0) + k4*E (erosion accumulation when buffering low + autocatalysis). Fit parameters to data via Bayesian inference
Test model predictions: simulate intervention scenarios (increase B at various ages) and compare to published partial reprogramming data for validation
Sensitivity analysis: vary metric definitions, cell type, and species (mouse vs. human where available) to assess robustness
tools: public data from GEO/Single Cell Portal
experiment.estimated_effort: 6-10 weeks compute + analysis; data curation 2 weeks, metric computation 2 weeks, causal inference 3 weeks, modeling 3 weeks
experiment.data_requirements: Longitudinal single-cell ATAC-seq spanning young-to-old (minimum 4 timepoints); ideal: Tabula Muris Senis (mouse, multiple ages), human PBMC aging cohorts, reprogramming time-courses. Minimum 500 cells per timepoint per cell type.
experiment.expected_positive: Granger F-statistic for buffering→erosion exceeds 4.0 (p<0.01) across ≥3 cell types; erosion acceleration inflection point consistently follows buffering decline by 2+ timepoints; ODE model with buffering-first structure fits data significantly better (ΔAIC > 10) than erosion-first alternative
experiment.expected_negative: Granger F-statistic for erosion→buffering exceeds that for buffering→erosion; erosion increases precede or coincide with buffering decline; symmetric or erosion-first ODE model fits equally well or better
experiment.null_hypothesis: H₀: There is no directional causal relationship between chromatin buffering capacity and epigenetic erosion during aging; any observed correlation reflects shared upstream drivers (e.g., mitochondrial dysfunction) without mechanistic coupling between the two processes.
experiment.statistical_test: Granger causality F-test with Bonferroni correction across cell types, alpha=0.01, minimum 4 temporal lags tested; model comparison via AIC/BIC with ΔAIC > 10 threshold for meaningful difference; bootstrap resampling (n=1000) for confidence intervals on temporal lag estimates
limitations: Observational data cannot definitively establish causation; Granger causality tests predictive precedence, not true mechanism
Metric definitions for 'buffering' from static snapshots are proxies; true buffering requires perturbation-response data rarely available in aging studies
Cell type heterogeneity and batch effects may confound temporal signals
Mouse-to-human translation uncertain
Published datasets may lack sufficient temporal resolution to detect the proposed 2-4 division lag
experiment.requires_followup: Definitive causal test requires CRISPRi knockdown of SMARCA4/SMARCA2 in young human fibroblasts with longitudinal single-cell ATAC-seq + CUT&Tag over 10+ passages, measuring whether buffering loss precedes erosion acceleration. Reciprocally, partial reprogramming (OSK) in aged cells with same readouts to test if buffering restoration precedes erosion reversal.

hypotheses.source_question: Does the disruption of long-range chromatin contacts during aging causally drive aberrant relocation of histone-modifying enzymes away from their baseline genomic targets, and does this enzyme redistribution in turn destabilize 3D genome architecture?
hypotheses.statement: We hypothesize that age-associated erosion of CTCF/cohesin-mediated long-range chromatin contacts (>500kb) causes redistribution of SIRT1 and PRC2 components away from their canonical genomic targets, and this causal relationship is directional: contact loss precedes enzyme relocation rather than enzyme departure destabilizing contacts.
hypotheses.mechanism: Long-range chromatin loops anchored by CTCF/cohesin create topological domains that function as three-dimensional retention platforms for histone-modifying enzymes through direct protein-protein interactions (CTCF-SIRT1, cohesin-PRC2) and local chromatin environment effects. During aging, stochastic cohesin loss and CTCF binding site methylation progressively dissolve these loops, eliminating the structural scaffolds that concentrate enzymes at appropriate loci. The released enzymes then redistribute to ectopic sites enriched for DNA damage or accessible chromatin, creating the epigenetic drift signature observed in senescent cells. Direction: Loop dissolution → enzyme release → ectopic binding (not reverse).
hypotheses.prediction: In aged versus young human fibroblast datasets, genomic loci that lose >50% of their long-range contact frequency (Hi-C interaction score) will show >3-fold reduction in SIRT1/EZH2 ChIP signal, and this contact-loss event will temporally precede enzyme loss by at least one replicative passage in time-resolved datasets. Computationally, contact strength at passage N will predict enzyme occupancy at passage N+1 with R² > 0.25, while enzyme occupancy at N will not predict contact strength at N+1 (R² < 0.10).
hypotheses.falsification_criteria: If enzyme occupancy loss at passage N predicts contact dissolution at passage N+1 with equal or greater strength (R² ≥ 0.25) compared to the reverse direction, this would refute the hypothesis that contact loss drives enzyme redistribution. Additionally, if loci losing contacts show no preferential loss of SIRT1/PRC2 binding compared to contact-stable loci (fold-change difference < 1.5), the mechanistic link would be refuted.
hypotheses.minimum_effect_size: Temporal Granger causality from contact strength to enzyme occupancy must exceed reverse direction by effect size Cohen's d > 0.5; cross-validation R² for contact→enzyme prediction must be >0.25; loci losing >50% contact strength must show >3-fold greater probability of enzyme loss versus contact-stable loci (odds ratio > 3.0, p < 0.01).

experiment.approach: Integrate publicly available time-resolved Hi-C and ChIP-seq datasets from replicatively aging human fibroblasts to test whether long-range contact decay temporally and statistically precedes histone-modifying enzyme redistribution, using Granger causality and predictive modeling frameworks.
steps: Obtain Hi-C data from GSE134067 (IMR90 replicative aging series) and matching ENCODE/Roadmap ChIP-seq for SIRT1, EZH2, SUZ12, and CTCF across multiple passages or age-matched primary fibroblast datasets (GSE118307, GSE38449)
Process Hi-C data with HiC-Pro and call loops/TADs using Mustache and HiCExplorer at 10kb and 50kb resolution; quantify long-range contact strength (>500kb) per anchor bin across passages
Align ChIP-seq peaks to loop anchors and quantify enzyme occupancy signal (normalized read density) at each anchor across passages
Build passage-resolved matrices: rows = genomic bins (loop anchors), columns = [contact_strength_P1, contact_strength_P2, ..., enzyme_signal_P1, enzyme_signal_P2, ...]
Apply vector autoregression (VAR) and Granger causality tests to determine whether contact strength at time T predicts enzyme occupancy at T+1 better than reverse
Train random forest models: (1) contact_T → enzyme_T+1, (2) enzyme_T → contact_T+1; compare cross-validated R² and feature importance
Stratify loci into contact-stable (≤20% change) versus contact-eroding (>50% loss) bins; compute odds ratio for enzyme loss in each stratum
Validate findings in independent dataset: 4D Nucleome IMR90 senescence time-course with available Hi-C + CUT&RUN for EZH2
experiment.data_requirements: Public Hi-C datasets: GSE134067 (IMR90 aging), 4D Nucleome senescence series; Public ChIP-seq: ENCODE SIRT1/EZH2/SUZ12 in fibroblasts, GSE118307 aging fibroblast epigenome data; minimum 3 time points with matched Hi-C and ChIP-seq
experiment.expected_positive: Contact strength at passage N significantly Granger-causes enzyme occupancy at N+1 (F-test p < 0.01), with predictive R² > 0.25; contact-eroding loci show >3-fold higher enzyme loss rate (OR > 3.0); reverse causality is not significant (p > 0.1, R² < 0.10)
experiment.expected_negative: Enzyme occupancy at passage N predicts contact strength at N+1 with R² ≥ 0.25, equal to or exceeding the forward direction; OR contact-eroding loci show no preferential enzyme loss (OR < 1.5); OR bidirectional Granger causality of equal strength, indicating feedback rather than directional causation
experiment.null_hypothesis: H₀: There is no directional causal relationship between long-range chromatin contact strength and histone-modifying enzyme occupancy during replicative aging; contact changes and enzyme redistribution occur independently or are jointly caused by a third factor without one preceding the other.
experiment.statistical_test: Granger causality F-test with lag order selected by BIC, alpha=0.01; permutation test (n=1000) for R² difference between forward and reverse predictive models, alpha=0.05; Fisher's exact test for odds ratio of enzyme loss in contact-eroding versus stable loci, alpha=0.01, power=0.80 (estimated n>200 loci per stratum)
limitations: Temporal resolution limited by available passage intervals (typically 5-10 PD gaps); finer dynamics may be missed
ChIP-seq population averaging may obscure single-cell heterogeneity in enzyme localization
Correlation/Granger causality cannot definitively prove causation; confounders (e.g., DNA damage, replication timing changes) may drive both
SIRT1 ChIP-seq has lower signal-to-noise than PRC2 components; may reduce power for SIRT1 analyses
Public datasets may lack perfectly matched time points for Hi-C and ChIP-seq
experiment.requires_followup: Wet-lab validation using auxin-degron acute cohesin depletion combined with HaloTag-SIRT1/EZH2 live imaging to directly observe enzyme redistribution kinetics upon loop dissolution; and reciprocal dCas9-mediated enzyme tethering to test whether artificial enzyme retention stabilizes contacts

hypotheses.source_question: Does chromatin buffering capacity determine the rate of epigenetic landscape deterioration during aging, and if so, what molecular mechanisms govern buffering capacity decline?
hypotheses.statement: We hypothesize that age-associated decline in chromatin buffering capacity, operationally defined as increased variance in chromatin accessibility across cell populations, causally precedes and predicts the rate of epigenetic landscape deterioration as measured by DNA methylation clock acceleration.
hypotheses.mechanism: Chromatin remodeling complexes (SWI/SNF, ISWI, CHD families) and histone chaperones (HIRA, ASF1, CAF-1) maintain chromatin accessibility homeostasis by actively restoring nucleosome positioning after transcriptional and replicative perturbations. With aging, declining expression or activity of these buffering factors permits stochastic drift in chromatin accessibility states, which subsequently propagates to DNA methylation patterns through altered transcription factor binding and recruitment of DNA methyltransferases. The causal direction is: buffering decline → accessibility variance increase → methylation drift → clock acceleration.
hypotheses.prediction: In longitudinal single-cell ATAC-seq and methylation datasets, chromatin accessibility variance measured at baseline (time T₀) will explain >15% of the variance in epigenetic clock acceleration rate measured at follow-up (time T₁), with accessibility variance temporally preceding methylation changes by at least one measurement interval.
hypotheses.falsification_criteria: If chromatin accessibility variance at baseline shows no significant correlation with subsequent epigenetic clock acceleration (r² < 0.05, p > 0.05), OR if methylation changes are found to precede accessibility variance increases in time-series analysis (Granger causality test favoring methylation → accessibility), the hypothesis would be refuted.
hypotheses.minimum_effect_size: Accessibility variance at T₀ must explain >15% of variance (r² > 0.15) in clock acceleration rate, with Granger causality F-statistic p < 0.01 supporting accessibility → methylation temporal ordering.

experiment.approach: Integrate existing longitudinal multi-omic aging datasets to test whether chromatin accessibility heterogeneity precedes and predicts DNA methylation clock acceleration, using temporal ordering analysis and variance decomposition.
steps: Acquire longitudinal datasets with paired single-cell ATAC-seq and DNA methylation from aging cohorts: prioritize Tabula Muris Senis, Human Cell Atlas aging datasets, and published longitudinal human PBMC studies (e.g., Stony Brook Longitudinal Study, GESTALT cohort)

For each tissue/timepoint, compute cell-to-cell chromatin accessibility variance across regulatory regions (promoters, enhancers, CTCF sites) as the primary buffering metric; normalize by mean accessibility to obtain coefficient of variation
Calculate DNA methylation-based epigenetic age (Horvath clock, PhenoAge, GrimAge) for matched samples and compute clock acceleration as residual from chronological age regression

Perform cross-lagged panel analysis: regress clock acceleration at T₁ on accessibility variance at T₀, controlling for baseline clock values, and compare with reverse model (variance at T₁ ~ methylation at T₀)
Apply Granger causality testing on time-series data to formally assess whether accessibility variance changes predict subsequent methylation changes better than vice versa
Identify specific genomic loci where accessibility variance most strongly predicts methylation drift using locus-by-locus correlation analysis; test enrichment for chromatin remodeler binding sites
Build a multivariate predictive model: does adding accessibility variance to age improve prediction of clock acceleration? Report incremental r² and likelihood ratio test
Validate findings in an independent cohort; if only cross-sectional data available, use age-stratified pseudo-longitudinal analysis with propensity score matching
tools: methylclock R package for epigenetic age calculation
lavaan R package for cross-lagged panel models
lmtest/vars R packages for Granger causality
experiment.estimated_effort: 3-4 weeks compute + analysis, assuming datasets are accessible
experiment.data_requirements: Longitudinal (≥2 timepoints, ideally ≥3) paired single-cell ATAC-seq and bulk/single-cell DNA methylation data from aging individuals or mice; minimum n=50 subjects for adequate power in cross-lagged models
experiment.expected_positive: Accessibility variance at T₀ significantly predicts clock acceleration at T₁ (r² > 0.15, p < 0.01), Granger causality supports accessibility → methylation direction (F-test p < 0.01), and high-variance loci are enriched for chromatin remodeler targets
experiment.expected_negative: Accessibility variance shows no predictive relationship with clock acceleration (r² < 0.05), OR Granger causality favors methylation → accessibility temporal ordering, OR variance and methylation changes are synchronous without detectable lead-lag relationship
experiment.null_hypothesis: H₀: Chromatin accessibility variance and DNA methylation clock acceleration are either uncorrelated or co-occur without temporal precedence—accessibility variance does not causally precede methylation drift in aging
experiment.statistical_test: Cross-lagged panel model with bootstrap confidence intervals (n=1000), Granger causality F-test with BIC-selected lag order, alpha=0.01 for primary hypothesis test, power >0.80 for r²=0.15 with n≥50
limitations: Publicly available longitudinal multi-omic aging datasets are rare; may require pseudo-longitudinal cross-sectional analysis which cannot establish true temporal precedence
Single-cell ATAC-seq technical noise may inflate variance estimates, requiring careful batch correction and quality filtering
Granger causality tests correlation patterns, not true causation—confounding variables (e.g., inflammation) could drive both processes
Different tissues may show different buffering-drift relationships; findings may not generalize across all tissue types
experiment.requires_followup: Wet-lab validation needed: (1) CRISPRi knockdown of top chromatin remodeler candidates identified from locus enrichment analysis, followed by longitudinal tracking of accessibility variance and methylation drift in cultured cells; (2) Stress-recovery assays measuring chromatin mark restoration kinetics in young vs. old primary cells to directly quantify buffering capacity

hypotheses.source_question: Does the rate and extent of histone deacetylase (HDAC) relocation to DNA damage sites causally determine the kinetics and fidelity of chromatin-mediated DNA repair, and does age-related dysfunction in this relocation contribute to genomic instability in aging?
hypotheses.statement: We hypothesize that age-related slowing of SIRT6 relocation kinetics to DNA double-strand breaks is a causal bottleneck for H3K56 deacetylation at damage sites, and that this delayed deacetylation—not reduced SIRT6 catalytic activity per se—drives the impaired DNA repair fidelity observed in replicatively senescent cells.
hypotheses.mechanism: SIRT6 must physically translocate from nucleolar/heterochromatic reservoirs to DNA damage foci within minutes of break induction to deacetylate H3K56, enabling 53BP1 recruitment and NHEJ pathway choice. In aged cells, reduced nuclear pore component expression (particularly NUP153 and TPR) and increased chromatin compaction slow SIRT6 intranuclear diffusion. This delayed arrival causes a temporal mismatch where competing acetylated chromatin states favor error-prone repair or persistent damage signaling, independent of total SIRT6 protein levels or in vitro deacetylase activity.
hypotheses.prediction: In replicatively senescent fibroblasts (population doubling >50), SIRT6 accumulation at laser-induced DNA damage foci will be delayed by at least 40% (t½ arrival >8 minutes vs <5 minutes in young cells), and this delay will correlate with >30% reduction in H3K56 deacetylation rate at damage sites, even when total nuclear SIRT6 protein levels are equivalent between conditions.
hypotheses.falsification_criteria: If senescent cells show equivalent or faster SIRT6 relocation kinetics compared to young cells (t½ ≤5 minutes) despite exhibiting impaired DNA repair, or if pharmacological restoration of relocation speed fails to rescue H3K56 deacetylation kinetics at damage sites, this would refute the hypothesis that relocation kinetics are the causal bottleneck.
hypotheses.minimum_effect_size: Correlation between SIRT6 relocation delay and H3K56 deacetylation rate: Pearson r > 0.5; Mediation analysis showing relocation kinetics explain >25% of the variance in repair fidelity difference between young and senescent cells; Effect size (Cohen's d) for relocation time difference between young and senescent >0.8.

experiment.approach: Computationally analyze existing single-cell and bulk multi-omics datasets from aging studies to identify signatures of HDAC/sirtuin mislocalization and correlate nuclear transport machinery expression with DNA repair efficiency markers across age groups.
steps: Download and preprocess single-cell RNA-seq datasets from human fibroblast aging studies (Tabula Sapiens, Aging Cell Atlas) and replicative senescence models (GEO: GSE130727, GSE63577)
Quantify expression trajectories of SIRT6, SIRT1, HDAC1/2 alongside nuclear pore components (NUP153, TPR, NUP50) and chromatin mobility factors (PARP1, CHD4) across replicative age/passage number

Analyze existing proteomics datasets with subcellular fractionation (nuclear vs cytoplasmic) from young vs senescent cells (PRIDE: PXD012340, PXD027354) to assess SIRT6 nuclear retention and mobility proxies

Mine existing ChIP-seq/CUT&Tag datasets for H3K56ac, H3K9ac, and γH2AX at DNA damage sites in young vs aged samples; compute deacetylation kinetics from time-course data where available (GEO: GSE118954)

Build a multivariate regression model predicting DNA repair efficiency scores (from existing γH2AX resolution or comet assay data) using: (1) SIRT6 expression, (2) nuclear transport gene signature, (3) their interaction term

Perform causal mediation analysis to test whether nuclear transport machinery expression mediates the relationship between cellular age and DNA repair fidelity, with SIRT6 nuclear abundance as the intermediary
Validate findings in independent cohort: analyze Genotype-Tissue Expression (GTEx) data for age-associated changes in SIRT6/nuclear pore component co-expression networks across tissues
tools: mediation R package for causal mediation analysis
experiment.estimated_effort: 3-4 weeks computational analysis with existing public datasets
experiment.data_requirements: Public scRNA-seq aging datasets (n>50 young, n>50 old samples), subcellular proteomics with fractionation data, ChIP-seq time courses post-DNA damage, matched transcriptomic and DNA repair phenotype data from same samples
experiment.expected_positive: Strong negative correlation (r < -0.5) between nuclear transport gene signature and cellular age; significant mediation effect where >25% of age-repair relationship is explained by predicted SIRT6 nuclear mobility; co-downregulation of NUP153/TPR with markers of repair deficiency in senescent clusters
experiment.expected_negative: No correlation between nuclear transport machinery expression and DNA repair efficiency; SIRT6 nuclear abundance unchanged or increased with age; mediation analysis shows <5% variance explained by transport pathway, indicating other mechanisms dominate
experiment.null_hypothesis: H₀: Nuclear transport gene expression and predicted SIRT6 localization dynamics do not mediate the relationship between cellular age and DNA repair efficiency; any age-related repair defects are fully explained by changes in total SIRT6 protein levels or catalytic activity.
experiment.statistical_test: Linear mixed-effects models with age as fixed effect, individual/batch as random effect, FDR-corrected q<0.05 for differential expression; Sobel test and bootstrap confidence intervals for mediation analysis, alpha=0.05; Pearson correlation with permutation-based p-values, n>100 cells per condition for single-cell analyses, power>0.80 for detecting r>0.3
limitations: Computational analysis infers relocation dynamics from expression/localization proxies rather than direct live-cell kinetic measurements
Existing datasets may lack sufficient temporal resolution post-damage to capture true kinetic differences
Subcellular proteomics fractionation may not distinguish chromatin-bound vs nucleoplasmic SIRT6
Confounding by other age-related changes in chromatin structure cannot be fully controlled computationally
Cross-sectional aging data cannot establish causality; would require longitudinal samples or interventional studies
experiment.requires_followup: Live-cell imaging with SIRT6-GFP in young vs senescent fibroblasts using laser microirradiation to directly measure relocation kinetics (t½ arrival at foci); FRAP experiments to measure SIRT6 intranuclear mobility; siRNA knockdown of NUP153/TPR to test whether transport perturbation recapitulates senescent phenotype in young cells; optogenetic or small-molecule enhancement of nuclear import to test rescue of repair kinetics

hypotheses.source_question: How do cohort-specific environmental exposures and selection effects during early life causally shape the age-trajectory of mortality risk, and can cohort mortality data be deconvolved to separate intrinsic senescence rates from cohort-specific frailty distributions?
hypotheses.statement: We hypothesize that early-life cohort exposures (famine, pandemic infection, air pollution) causally accelerate the intrinsic rate of senescence (Gompertz β parameter) rather than simply elevating baseline mortality (Gompertz α parameter), and that this acceleration is mediated by permanent shifts in cohort frailty distributions that can be quantitatively deconvolved from aggregate mortality data.
hypotheses.mechanism: Early-life environmental insults during critical developmental windows induce persistent physiological damage (e.g., epigenetic reprogramming, organ reserve depletion, chronic inflammation) that increases the rate at which mortality risk accelerates with age, not merely the starting level of risk. This manifests as a steeper Gompertz slope (β) in exposed cohorts, reflecting faster biological aging. The cohort-level effect operates through a rightward shift and increased variance in the latent frailty distribution, which can be statistically separated from period effects and intrinsic senescence using hierarchical survival models.
hypotheses.prediction: Cohorts exposed to severe early-life adversity (famine, 1918 influenza, high childhood pollution) will exhibit a Gompertz β parameter at least 15% higher than adjacent unexposed cohorts from the same country, after controlling for period effects and secular mortality trends, with this excess slope persisting across the entire adult lifespan (ages 40-90).
hypotheses.falsification_criteria: If exposed cohorts show elevated Gompertz α (baseline mortality) but statistically equivalent or lower Gompertz β (mortality acceleration rate) compared to unexposed cohorts—indicating that early-life adversity affects only initial frailty level without altering senescence rate—the causal mechanism proposed would be refuted. Specifically, a β ratio (exposed/unexposed) with 95% credible interval fully containing 1.0 would refute the hypothesis.
hypotheses.minimum_effect_size: Gompertz β ratio (exposed/unexposed cohort) > 1.15 with 95% Bayesian credible interval excluding 1.0; alternatively, posterior probability P(β_exposed > β_unexposed) > 0.95

experiment.approach: Apply Bayesian hierarchical survival models to multi-country cohort life tables spanning documented early-life exposure events, using instrumental variable logic where historical shocks serve as natural experiments to estimate causal effects on mortality trajectory parameters.
steps: Compile cohort life tables from Human Mortality Database for Netherlands (1944-45 famine cohorts), USA/UK/Sweden (1918-19 influenza cohorts), and UK (pre/post Clean Air Act 1956 cohorts), with age-specific mortality rates from ages 0-90+ where available

Construct exposure indicators: binary and dose-response measures for Dutch Hunger Winter (gestational/early childhood exposure by birth month), 1918 flu (in-utero and infant exposure by birth quarter), and childhood pollution (pre-1956 vs post-1960 UK birth cohorts)

Implement Bayesian hierarchical Gompertz-Makeham model: log(μ_x) = α_c + β_c * x + γ_p, where α_c and β_c are cohort-specific, γ_p captures period effects, with latent frailty modeled as gamma-distributed with cohort-specific shape and scale parameters
Fit models using Stan/PyMC with weakly informative priors; estimate posterior distributions for α_c, β_c, and frailty parameters for each cohort
Test primary hypothesis: compute posterior distribution of β_exposed / β_unexposed for each natural experiment; evaluate whether 95% credible intervals exclude 1.0 and posterior P(ratio > 1.15)

Perform sensitivity analyses: (a) age-period-cohort decomposition to isolate cohort effects, (b) placebo tests using adjacent unexposed cohorts, (c) dose-response analysis where exposure intensity data exists

Validate frailty decomposition: test whether recovered frailty distributions predict cause-specific mortality patterns (cardiovascular, respiratory, cancer) using linked cause-of-death data from national registries
Cross-validate across countries: test whether cohort effects on β are consistent across Netherlands, UK, USA, Sweden for similar exposure types
tools: cause-of-death data from WHO Mortality Database
historical exposure documentation from published studies
experiment.estimated_effort: 3-4 months for data assembly, model development, and sensitivity analyses
experiment.data_requirements: Cohort life tables with single-year-of-birth resolution from Human Mortality Database (freely available for 40+ countries); historical documentation of exposure events (published literature); cause-of-death data from WHO or national statistical offices (partially restricted)
experiment.expected_positive: Exposed cohorts show β ratios > 1.15 with 95% credible intervals excluding 1.0; effect is consistent across multiple natural experiments; frailty decomposition reveals elevated variance in exposed cohorts; cause-of-death patterns consistent with accelerated multi-system senescence
experiment.expected_negative: β ratios cluster around 1.0 with credible intervals fully containing 1.0; exposed cohorts show elevated α but not β; frailty distributions indistinguishable between exposed and unexposed cohorts—indicating early-life effects operate through one-time damage rather than altered aging rate
experiment.null_hypothesis: H₀: Early-life cohort exposures do not causally affect the Gompertz mortality acceleration parameter (β); any observed cohort differences in mortality reflect only baseline risk differences (α) or period effects, with β_exposed / β_unexposed = 1.0
experiment.statistical_test: Bayesian hypothesis testing: compute posterior probability P(β_exposed > 1.15 × β_unexposed | data) with decision threshold of 0.95; additionally report Bayes factors comparing full model to constrained model with β_exposed = β_unexposed; sensitivity analysis using frequentist mixed-effects Cox models with cohort×age interaction terms
limitations: Cannot fully rule out selection effects (differential survival of robust individuals in exposed cohorts may bias β estimates downward)
Historical exposure data may have measurement error in timing and intensity
Age-period-cohort identification problem requires strong modeling assumptions
Life table data aggregates heterogeneous individuals; individual-level data would strengthen causal inference
Cannot directly observe biological mechanisms without biomarker data
experiment.requires_followup: Validation in cohort biobanks (e.g., UK Biobank, Lifelines) linking individual-level early-life exposure proxies to epigenetic clocks and inflammatory markers to confirm biological mediation of the statistical cohort effects on senescence rate

hypotheses.source_question: How does the substrate specificity of individual sirtuin isoforms (SIRT1-7) differentially regulate histone deacetylation patterns at longevity-associated genomic loci, and does this specificity change with age?
hypotheses.statement: We hypothesize that age-associated epigenetic drift at longevity-regulating genes is caused by a loss of SIRT6-specific H3K9ac deacetylation activity, rather than by changes in SIRT6 expression levels, such that SIRT6 binding is maintained but catalytic output per binding event decreases with age.
hypotheses.mechanism: SIRT6 directly deacetylates H3K9ac at promoters of stress-response and metabolic genes that regulate lifespan. With age, post-translational modifications or cofactor availability changes reduce SIRT6 catalytic efficiency without altering its genomic occupancy. This creates a dissociation between SIRT6 ChIP signal and H3K9ac levels at target loci, leading to aberrant transcriptional activation of aging-associated genes. The causal direction is: reduced SIRT6 catalytic activity → increased H3K9ac at target promoters → dysregulated longevity gene expression.
hypotheses.prediction: At SIRT6-bound longevity-associated loci (defined by overlap with aging gene signatures), the ratio of H3K9ac ChIP signal to SIRT6 ChIP signal will increase by ≥1.5-fold in old versus young mouse liver tissue, while absolute SIRT6 binding signal remains within 20% of young levels.
hypotheses.falsification_criteria: If H3K9ac/SIRT6-binding ratios at longevity-associated loci remain constant or decrease with age (ratio change <1.2-fold), OR if SIRT6 binding itself decreases proportionally with H3K9ac increases (correlation r > 0.7 between SIRT6 loss and H3K9ac gain), the hypothesis of maintained binding with reduced catalytic output would be refuted.
hypotheses.minimum_effect_size: H3K9ac/SIRT6-binding ratio increase ≥1.5-fold at >30% of SIRT6-bound longevity-associated loci (n ≥ 200 loci); correlation between SIRT6 binding maintenance and H3K9ac accumulation r < 0.3 (indicating dissociation rather than co-loss).

experiment.approach: Integrate publicly available SIRT6 and H3K9ac ChIP-seq data from young and old mouse tissues with longevity gene signatures to quantify whether SIRT6 binding-to-deacetylation efficiency changes with age at functionally relevant loci.
steps: 1. Compile longevity-associated gene set (n~500-1000) from GenAge database, Tabula Muris Senis age-differential genes, and curated lifespan-extension gene lists
2. Download public SIRT6 ChIP-seq datasets from young (3-4 month) and old (18-24 month) mouse liver (ENCODE, GEO: GSE datasets from Mostoslavsky lab and others)
3. Download matched H3K9ac ChIP-seq data from same tissues/ages (ENCODE mouse ENCODE, Tabula Muris consortium)
4. Process all datasets through uniform pipeline: alignment (bowtie2), peak calling (MACS2), signal quantification (deepTools bamCompare)
5. Define SIRT6-bound regions at promoters (TSS ± 2kb) in young tissue; calculate SIRT6 signal and H3K9ac signal at these regions in both ages
6. Compute H3K9ac/SIRT6 signal ratio for each SIRT6-bound promoter in young vs old; stratify by longevity-association status
7. Statistical comparison: paired Wilcoxon test for ratio changes; linear regression to test if SIRT6 binding loss explains H3K9ac gain (test r < 0.3)
8. Functional enrichment: test if high-ratio-increase loci are enriched in specific longevity pathways (autophagy, DNA repair, metabolic regulation)
9. Validate signal specificity using SIRT6-KO ChIP-seq data as negative control for binding peaks
experiment.data_requirements: Public ChIP-seq: SIRT6 and H3K9ac from young and old mouse liver (minimum 2 biological replicates per condition); SIRT6-KO liver ChIP-seq; RNA-seq from matched tissues for expression correlation
experiment.expected_positive: H3K9ac/SIRT6 ratio increases ≥1.5-fold with age at >30% of SIRT6-bound longevity gene promoters; SIRT6 absolute binding stable (Pearson r < 0.3 between SIRT6 loss and H3K9ac gain), confirming maintained binding with reduced catalytic output.
experiment.expected_negative: H3K9ac/SIRT6 ratio unchanged (<1.2-fold) with age, OR strong positive correlation (r > 0.7) between SIRT6 binding loss and H3K9ac gain, indicating proportional co-loss rather than efficiency decline.
experiment.null_hypothesis: H₀: The ratio of H3K9ac to SIRT6 binding signal at longevity-associated loci does not change with age (fold change = 1.0, 95% CI includes 1.0), indicating that any H3K9ac accumulation is explained entirely by proportional SIRT6 binding loss.
experiment.statistical_test: Paired Wilcoxon signed-rank test for ratio changes across loci, alpha=0.05, with Benjamini-Hochberg correction for multiple comparisons; linear regression with permutation test (n=1000) to assess binding-acetylation correlation, power analysis targeting 80% power to detect effect size d=0.5
limitations: Public datasets may have batch effects or tissue heterogeneity between young/old samples
Cannot directly measure catalytic activity from ChIP-seq—ratio is a proxy
Confounding by other H3K9ac-modifying enzymes (p300/CBP writers, other HDACs) at same loci
Mouse liver findings may not generalize to other tissues or species
ChIP-seq signal ratios are semi-quantitative and sensitive to normalization methods
experiment.requires_followup: Wet-lab validation with in vitro SIRT6 activity assays on recombinant enzyme from young vs old tissue lysates, plus CUT&RUN-seq with spike-in normalization to confirm quantitative ratio changes.

hypotheses.source_question: Can machine learning models trained on cohort mortality data systematically detect and quantify historical echoes as distinct mortality signatures, enabling prospective identification of cohorts at elevated late-life mortality risk?
hypotheses.statement: We hypothesize that an unsupervised anomaly detection framework applied to birth-cohort-stratified mortality trajectories will identify historical echo signatures with significantly higher sensitivity and specificity than traditional period-effect decomposition methods, enabling prospective prediction of excess late-life mortality in cohorts with documented early-life adversity.
hypotheses.mechanism: Historical echoes arise from developmental programming and selective survival during early-life adversity, creating cohort-specific mortality signatures that deviate from smooth secular trends. Traditional age-period-cohort (APC) models confound these signatures with period effects because they assume linear additivity across dimensions. A machine learning anomaly detector trained on residuals from baseline mortality surfaces can isolate non-linear cohort deviations that represent biological scarring from historical events, as these deviations should cluster around known adversity years and propagate forward into late-life mortality with characteristic lag structures.
hypotheses.prediction: The ML anomaly detection method will achieve area under the ROC curve (AUC) ≥ 0.80 for classifying cohorts as echo-affected versus unaffected (ground truth: independently documented historical adversity events), compared to AUC ≤ 0.65 for standard APC decomposition residual analysis, when tested on held-out country-cohort combinations.
hypotheses.falsification_criteria: If the ML anomaly detector achieves AUC < 0.70 on the echo classification task, OR if it performs no better than APC residual analysis (AUC difference < 0.10 with overlapping 95% confidence intervals), OR if detected anomalies show no temporal clustering around documented historical adversity events (chi-square test for non-random distribution p > 0.05), the hypothesis would be refuted.
hypotheses.minimum_effect_size: AUC improvement ≥ 0.15 over APC baseline (e.g., 0.80 vs 0.65); detected echo signatures must explain ≥ 15% of cohort-specific mortality variance beyond age and period effects; prospective mortality prediction for affected cohorts must show hazard ratio ≥ 1.20 relative to unaffected birth-adjacent cohorts.

experiment.approach: Develop and validate an unsupervised anomaly detection pipeline for birth-cohort mortality data, benchmarked against traditional APC decomposition, with ground-truth labels derived from an independent historical adversity database.
steps: Download cohort life tables from Human Mortality Database for ≥15 countries with records spanning 1850-2020, stratified by single birth year and age at death
Construct mortality surfaces (log mortality rate vs age vs birth year) for each country; apply Lee-Carter model to extract baseline secular trend and age structure
Compute residual mortality surfaces by subtracting Lee-Carter predictions; these residuals contain candidate echo signals
Implement three anomaly detection algorithms on residuals: (a) isolation forest, (b) variational autoencoder reconstruction error, (c) Gaussian mixture model outlier scores

Compile independent ground-truth database of historical adversity events (wars, famines, pandemics, economic crises) with affected birth cohorts, severity scores, and geographic scope from peer-reviewed historiography
Label cohorts as echo-affected or unaffected based on temporal overlap with adversity events (±2 years of birth); create training (60%), validation (20%), and test (20%) splits stratified by country
Train supervised classifiers (gradient boosting, neural network) on anomaly features to predict echo status; tune hyperparameters on validation set
Evaluate classification performance (AUC, sensitivity, specificity) on held-out test cohorts; compare to baseline APC residual magnitude classifier
For cohorts identified as echo-affected, project excess mortality into late life (ages 60-90) and compare predictions against observed mortality in cohorts now reaching those ages
Perform sensitivity analyses: (a) leave-one-country-out cross-validation, (b) varying adversity severity thresholds, (c) alternative baseline mortality models (CBD, Renshaw-Haberman)
tools: Historical adversity database (constructed from Correlates of War, EM-DAT disaster database, World Famines bibliography)
experiment.estimated_effort: 3-4 months: 1 month data compilation and preprocessing, 1 month model development and training, 1 month validation and benchmarking, 2-4 weeks sensitivity analyses and manuscript preparation
experiment.data_requirements: Human Mortality Database access (freely available with registration); historical adversity event database compiled from Correlates of War Project, EM-DAT international disaster database, and systematic literature review of documented famines and pandemics; minimum 500 country-cohort combinations with ≥40 years of mortality follow-up each
experiment.expected_positive: ML anomaly detector achieves AUC ≥ 0.80 for echo classification with ≥0.15 AUC improvement over APC baseline; detected anomalies cluster significantly around documented adversity years (p < 0.001); prospective mortality predictions for 1918 influenza and Dutch Hunger Winter cohorts show HR ≥ 1.20 for late-life mortality
experiment.expected_negative: ML anomaly detector achieves AUC < 0.70 or shows no significant improvement over APC baseline (AUC difference < 0.10, overlapping CIs); detected anomalies distributed randomly across years with no clustering around adversity events; prospective predictions fail to identify excess mortality in cohorts with known early-life exposures
experiment.null_hypothesis: H₀: Unsupervised anomaly detection on cohort mortality residuals provides no better classification of historical-echo-affected cohorts than traditional APC decomposition residual analysis, and detected anomalies are randomly distributed with respect to documented historical adversity events.
experiment.statistical_test: Primary: DeLong test for AUC comparison between ML detector and APC baseline, two-sided alpha = 0.05, with bootstrap 95% CI (10,000 replicates). Secondary: Chi-square test for non-random temporal clustering of detected anomalies around adversity years. Tertiary: Cox proportional hazards model comparing late-life mortality between predicted echo-affected vs unaffected cohorts, with HR 95% CI excluding 1.0 at alpha = 0.05.
limitations: Ground-truth labeling depends on completeness of historical adversity documentation, which is biased toward well-documented European events
Cannot distinguish genuine biological echoes from data quality artifacts in historical mortality records
Confounding between early-life adversity and socioeconomic conditions that persist across the lifespan
Model trained on historical data may not generalize to contemporary cohorts with different adversity patterns (e.g., environmental exposures)
Cannot determine whether detected signatures reflect developmental programming vs selective survival without individual-level data
experiment.requires_followup: Validation of proposed biological mechanism requires longitudinal cohort studies with biomarker data (epigenetic clocks, inflammatory markers, telomere length) collected from individuals born during documented adversity events, correlated with mortality outcomes, to confirm that detected population-level signatures reflect individual-level biological scarring rather than purely demographic composition effects.

hypotheses.source_question: What systematic biases in epigenetic clock training cause divergence between chronological age prediction accuracy and biological age estimation validity, and how can clock architectures be redesigned to optimize for one objective without compromising the other?
hypotheses.statement: We hypothesize that epigenetic clocks trained to maximize mortality prediction (C-index optimization) will select a substantially different CpG feature set than clocks trained to minimize chronological age prediction error (MAE optimization), with fewer than 40% overlapping CpGs in the top 500 features, and the mortality-optimized clock will show at least 50% smaller age-acceleration changes in response to known biological interventions (caloric restriction, exercise) compared to the chronological-age-optimized clock.
hypotheses.mechanism: Chronological age prediction selects CpGs that track deterministic time-dependent methylation drift (birth-cohort effects, cumulative environmental exposures, passive epigenetic entropy), while mortality prediction selects CpGs functionally linked to senescence pathways, immune dysfunction, and metabolic dysregulation. The causal direction is: training objective → CpG feature selection → differential sensitivity to biological versus chronological aging signals. This mechanistic divergence arises because chronological age is a confounder for mortality, not a mediator—thus optimizing directly for mortality bypasses sites that merely correlate with calendar time.
hypotheses.prediction: When trained on identical multi-cohort data, a mortality-optimized elastic net model (maximizing Harrell's C-index for 10-year all-cause mortality) will share <40% of its top 500 CpG features with a chronological-age-optimized model (minimizing MAE), and the mortality clock's predicted age acceleration will change by ≤50% as much as the chronological clock's acceleration in intervention cohorts where biological age should improve (caloric restriction, sustained exercise programs) while chronological age remains constant.
hypotheses.falsification_criteria: If the two model types share >60% of their top 500 CpG features, OR if the mortality-optimized clock shows equal or greater age-acceleration changes (≥100% of chronological clock's change) in biological intervention cohorts, the hypothesis is refuted. This would indicate that chronological and biological age prediction are not methodologically separable at the feature level.
hypotheses.minimum_effect_size: CpG overlap <40% (Jaccard index <0.25 for top 500 features); intervention response ratio <0.5 (mortality clock Δage-acceleration / chronological clock Δage-acceleration); mortality clock C-index improvement >0.02 over chronological clock for mortality prediction

experiment.approach: Train parallel epigenetic clocks with divergent optimization objectives on harmonized multi-cohort methylation data, then quantitatively compare CpG feature selection, predictive performance, and sensitivity to biological interventions.
steps: Acquire and harmonize Illumina 450K/EPIC methylation data from GEO/ArrayExpress for cohorts with both chronological age and mortality follow-up: Framingham Heart Study (GEO: GSE40279, GSE36064), InCHIANTI (GSE26126), and Generation Scotland (access via EGA)
Preprocess data uniformly: BMIQ normalization, remove probes with >5% missing, filter cross-reactive probes per Chen et al. 2013, impute remaining missing values via k-NN
Split data 70/15/15 into training/validation/test sets, stratified by cohort, age decile, and mortality status
Train Model A (chronological): elastic net regression minimizing MAE to chronological age, hyperparameter-tuned via 10-fold CV on training set
Train Model B (mortality): elastic net Cox regression maximizing Harrell's C-index for all-cause mortality (10-year follow-up), hyperparameter-tuned via 10-fold CV
Extract top 500 non-zero coefficients from each model; compute Jaccard similarity index for feature overlap
Evaluate both models on held-out test set: MAE for chronological prediction, C-index for mortality prediction, cross-task performance (Model A on mortality, Model B on chronological)

Apply both clocks to intervention cohorts: CALERIE trial methylation data (caloric restriction, if accessible), or exercise intervention cohorts (GSE60281), computing Δage-acceleration pre/post intervention
Compare Δage-acceleration magnitude between clocks; compute ratio of mortality clock change to chronological clock change
Perform pathway enrichment (KEGG, GO Biological Process) on CpGs unique to each model to characterize functional divergence
tools: R/minfi and ChAMP for methylation preprocessing
survival package for Cox models and C-index
experiment.estimated_effort: 4-6 weeks: 1 week data acquisition/harmonization, 1 week preprocessing, 2 weeks model training/optimization, 1 week intervention cohort analysis, 1 week pathway analysis and manuscript preparation
experiment.data_requirements: Minimum 3,000 samples with chronological age and mortality follow-up across ≥2 cohorts; intervention cohort with ≥50 paired pre/post samples; 450K or EPIC array platform with >400,000 CpGs post-QC
experiment.expected_positive: Jaccard index <0.25 for top 500 CpGs; mortality clock shows ≤50% of chronological clock's Δage-acceleration in intervention cohorts; distinct pathway enrichment (chronological clock: cell cycle, DNA repair; mortality clock: inflammation, immune senescence)
experiment.expected_negative: Jaccard index >0.43 (>60% overlap); mortality clock shows ≥100% of chronological clock's Δage-acceleration in interventions; no significant pathway divergence between model feature sets
experiment.null_hypothesis: H₀: CpG feature sets selected by chronological-age-optimized and mortality-optimized epigenetic clocks are drawn from the same underlying distribution, with expected Jaccard overlap consistent with random subsampling (>50%), and both clocks respond equivalently to biological interventions affecting aging rate.
experiment.statistical_test: Jaccard index permutation test (10,000 permutations, α=0.01) for feature overlap; paired Wilcoxon signed-rank test for Δage-acceleration comparison in intervention cohorts (α=0.05, power=0.80 for n≥30 paired samples); Fisher's exact test for pathway enrichment (FDR<0.05)
limitations: CALERIE methylation data may not be publicly accessible, requiring substitution with exercise intervention cohorts
Mortality follow-up windows vary across cohorts, potentially introducing heterogeneity
Cannot distinguish causal CpGs from correlated markers without Mendelian randomization, which requires additional mQTL data
Elastic net feature selection is stochastic; results may vary with regularization strength
Cross-cohort batch effects may persist despite harmonization, inflating apparent model differences
experiment.requires_followup: Mendelian randomization using mQTLs (from GoDMC or similar) to establish causal direction for divergent CpG sets; prospective validation in an independent cohort with long-term mortality tracking; experimental perturbation of top discriminating CpGs in cellular models to confirm functional relevance
